answers: Paul Hindemith ("HIN-duh-mit") (The opera is Mathis der Maler.)
parts: This conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic under the Third Reich led an infamous 1942 performance of Beethoven's Ninth for Hitler's birthday.

Furtwängler nonetheless championed this composer, whose works were banned by the Nazis in 1936. His best-known opera opens with an "Angelic Concert" in which bright G major chords clash with rising G minor figures played by the woodwinds.

Werner Egk's ("VAIR-nur ek'z") opera based on this Henrik Ibsen play was met with Hitler and Goebbels's approval. Edvard Grieg's incidental music to this play includes the piece "In the Hall of the Mountain King".

answers: obeah [or obi, or obeya, or obia]
Kongo people [or BaKongo, MuKongo, EsiKongo, or MwisiKongo; accept Kingdom of Kongo, Kongo dia Ntotila, Wene wa Kongo, or Reino do Congo]
parts: Name this form of folk healing and sorcery based on Akan and Igbo practices. It's most widespread in Jamaica.
Obeah is sometimes called the "Jamaican" version of this syncretic religion widely practiced in Haiti, which venerates Bondye ("bone-DYEH") and loas ("LWAH'z").

The related but distinct Jamaican tradition of myal, which focuses on spiritual connection rather than magic, is rooted in the native religion of this African people. Their namesake kingdom converted to Catholicism under Afonso I, born Mvemba a Nzinga.

answers: auto-da-fés [or autos-da-fé; prompt on inquisitions or trials]
parts: Name this pioneering 1967 anthology of New Wave science fiction stories compiled by Harlan Ellison. Many of its entries went on to win Hugo and Nebula awards.
This author of the short story "Nightfall" and the Foundation trilogy wrote the foreword to Dangerous Visions.

Dangerous Visions includes a story by Roger Zelazny titled for these events, in which futuristic bullfights feature human "mechadors" who fight cars. In Candide, Pangloss survives a hanging during one of these events held after the Lisbon earthquake.

answers: cross-sectional area AND the wetted perimeter
parts: Name this general type of technology whose theoretical underpinning is Pascal's principle. Modern automobile brakes and namesake "presses" use this technology, which involves using fluids to transmit and modify forces.
The hydraulic radius of a conduit is defined as the ratio of these two quantities characterizing the geometry of the cross-section. Give both.
In robotics, hydraulics are often used to power these components. This term describes components of a machine that create the motion.
Name this politician whose tour laid the groundwork for the Second Africa-Asia Conference in Algiers, the intended successor to the earlier Bandung Conference where this man stole the show.
This African leader was almost assassinated during Zhou's 1964 meeting with him. He had earlier attended the Bandung Conference representing the Gold Coast.
Zhou ended his Africa tour by speaking before a rally in this African capital city. A U.S. operation here was the subject of the movie Black Hawk Down.

answers: The Music Lesson, Woman Seated at a Virginal [or A Lady at the Virginals with a Gentleman; do not prompt or accept "Lady Seated at a Virginal" or "Lady Standing at a Virginal"]
Jan Vermeer van Delft [or Johannes Vermeer]
parts: Name this painting, which is set in a blue-and-white tiled room. A white jug sits on a multicolored rug to the right of a man instructing a woman in this painting.
This Dutch artist's The Music Lesson is one of his many paintings of women playing virginals. He's best known for Girl with a Pearl Earring.

Paintings in this genre appear on the virginal's interior in Vermeer's paintings of ladies "seated" and "standing" at virginals. Joachim Patinir ("YO-ah-keem PAH-tih-neer") invented a variety of this genre popular in the Renaissance.

answers: Republic of Equatorial Guinea [or República de Guinea Ecuatorial]
parts: The highest point in Dutch territory is Mount Scenery on this island. Due to its rocky coastline, this island once only had a single point of entry - a set of 800 hand-carved steps called "The Ladder".
This archipelago's Mount Teide ("teh-EE-day"), found on its island of Tenerife ("teh-neh-REE-fay"), is both the highest point in Spanish territory and the highest point on any Atlantic archipelago.

This country's highest point is Pico Basilé ("PEE-koh bah-see-LAY") on the island of Bioko. The name of this country's island of Annobón is derived from Portuguese, even though this African country's official language is Spanish.
Name this Hawaiian politician, who worked with Birch Bayh to pass Title IX in 1972. In 1964, this politician became the first Asian-American woman to serve in Congress.
In 1965, Mink introduced the first federal child-care bill to Congress, which was a part of this set of Lyndon Johnson programs that sought to eliminate racial injustice and poverty.

Mink and a congresswoman from this state, Bella Abzug, travelled to Paris to help resume the Paris Peace Accords. Abzug failed to primary Daniel Moynihan in the 1976 race to become this state's senator.

answers: W. H. Auden [or Wystan Hugh Auden]
commencements [or graduations; accept Victory Commencement or Kenyon Commencement] (The second clue is from "This is Water" by David Foster Wallace.)
parts: Name this poem which seeks to "undo the folded lie" by declaring "We must love one another or die".
"September 1, 1939" is this author's poem about the start of World War II. He wrote "stop all the clocks" to open his poem "Funeral Blues".

Auden wrote his poem "Under Which Lyre" in response to a "Victory" example of these events held after World War II. An essay originally presented at one of these events begins with an anecdote about two fish to explain how "obvious, important realities" are among the "hardest to see".

answers: pH [or the power of hydrogen; accept acidity or basicity]
parts: Name this quantity, which is measured somewhat qualitatively by dipping litmus paper into a solution and observing the color change.
This material is used to make the working electrode in electrochemical pH meters. Indium tin oxide is a commonly-used conductive coating for this material.

This quantity can introduce errors in electrochemical pH measurements. It is the difference in electric potential that results from ion diffusion when two electrolytic solutions with different concentrations are placed in contact.

answers: polis [or poleis; accept polises even though that's not the correct plural; prompt on city or city-state; do not accept or prompt on "town"]
parts: Give the Greek term for these entities whose formation marks the beginning of the Archaic period, and of which there were over 1,000 by the Classical period. Examples include Megara and Miletus.
This polis attributed its synoecism to its legendary king Theseus, who joined all the towns of nearby Attica into one political unit.

Unlike most poleis ("poh-lay-EES"), this city-state's synoecism is firmly dated to 471 B.C. by Strabo. The judges of the Olympic games, or Hellanodikai ("hel-lah-NOH-dee-kye"), were picked from citizens of this nearby polis.

answers: epiglottis (The second sentence refers to aspiration pneumonia.)
parts: Tay-Sachs and Niemann-Pick disease can produce a "cherry-red" spot on this structure, which contains a high proportion of cone cells. The fovea lies within this structure.

Infection by Haemophilus influenzae can result in a "cherry-red" or "thumbprinting" appearance of this structure. Klebsiella and anaerobes may cause a form of pneumonia characterized by the malfunction of this structure.
The skin is described as "cherry-red" in poisonings due to this gas, which binds to hemoglobin with an affinity 200 times greater than that of oxygen.

answers: riders [accept The Riders or Riders in the Chariot or Riders of the Purple Sage]
parts: Name this contemporary Australian author who described the travails of the working-class Pickle and Lamb families in the novel Cloudstreet.
Winton's novels Shallows deals with the commerce in these animals. In another novel, a white one is pursued by Captain Ahab.

In Winton's novel titled for this noun, Jennifer fails to join her family in their move to Ireland. It's also the first title noun of a Peter Carey novel whose characters experience visions of Ezekiel, as well as a Zane Grey novel about the Withersteen family.
Name this monarch, who abdicated her country’s monarchy in 2013 in favor of her son, Willem-Alexander. During her reign, Aruba seceded from her country.
Beatrix, the granddaughter of Queen Wilhelmina, was the queen of this country. Its major shipping port of Rotterdam was subjected to massive bombing during World War II.

Roel van Duyn, the founder of Provo, credits the offshoot group “Baastards” with leading the first Dutch protest against this conflict. Harold Wilson sent the Davies Mission to attempt to negotiate an end to this conflict.

answers: false friends [or fauxs amis; prompt on false cognates]
doublets [accept etymological twins or twinlings; prompt on twins]
parts: Name these words that have a common etymological origin, often from a shared parent language, such as the English night and the German Nacht.

This informal term denotes words which appear to be cognates and may be related, but have totally different meanings; a common example is the English embarrassed and the Spanish embarazada ("em-bah-rah-SAH-dah"), which means "pregnant".
This term denotes cognates within the same language that may have meanings that are slightly or even totally different, such as ward and guard.

answers: Hong Kong [or HKSAR, or Hong Kong Special Administrative Region]
shadows [accept Approaching Shadow or In Praise of Shadows]
parts: Ho was a major practitioner of this sort of photography, which involves taking candid photos in the namesake public places. It was pioneered by Henri Cartier-Bresson.
Ho made his name taking street photos of this city. For the book Architecture of Density, Michael Wolf took photos of this city's skyscrapers, which include Central Plaza and the HSBC building.

Ho created his most iconic photograph, titled for an "Approaching" one of these objects, by editing a photo of his cousin so that a triangular-shaped one begins at her feet. These objects title several photo books by Hiroshi Sugimoto, one of which was inspired by an essay about "violent" artificial lighting.

answers: Septuagint [or Septuaginta; or E Metáphrasis ton Hebdomékonta; accept versio septuaginta interpretum; prompt on Greek Old Testament]
Zoroastrianism [or Zoroastrian religion; prompt on Mazdaism]
parts: Give this Greek term for figures including Nomos and Eusebia, who personified law and piety, respectively. It was later used to translate the term for "idol" in the Hebrew Bible.
The term daimon was first used for evil spirits and idols in this oldest extant Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible, whose name refers to its supposed 72 translators.
Similarly, this religion uses the term daeva, which once referred to common gods and spirits, to denote evil beings. It contrasts them with the venerated ahuras, such as Ahura Mazda.

answers: self-energy of the electron [prompt on self-energy or self-interaction; prompt on mass of the electron or effective mass of the electron]
polarization [accept polarized or vacuum polarization; do not accept or prompt on "polarizability"]
parts: Name this quantity, whose one-loop Feynman diagram is a horizontal solid line, with a wavy line branching off the solid line on the left, then rejoining it on the right.
The self-energy of the (emphasize) photon causes the vacuum to transiently acquire this property. This property's "density" equals the induced dipole moment per unit volume.
A self-energy term appears in precise calculations of the mass of these very light leptons, which "oscillate" between three flavors.

answers: cosmological argument [or causal argument; accept kalam cosmological argument]
argument from degree [or degrees argument, or henological argument]
parts: This argument, which holds that a "necessary existent" created all contingent things, was developed extensively by scholars in the kalam tradition. It argues that God serves as the "prime mover" in the universe.
This Archbishop of Canterbury wrote the Proslogion, which advances the ontological argument for God's existence.

The fourth of Thomas Aquinas's five proofs from the Summa Theologica is this argument, which states that since all beings have different levels of perfection, there must be one being which is absolutely perfect, and that is God.

answers: Chinese-American [or Han Chinese; prompt on Asian-American]
M. Butterfly [do not accept or prompt on "Madame Butterfly"]
parts: Give this ethnicity of immigrant characters in many of David Henry Hwang's plays. It's also the ethnicity of Maxine Hong Kingston.
Hwang is best known for this play about the civil servant René Gallimard, who falls in love with the opera singer Song Liling, who disguises herself as a man.

In this other Hwang play, the character Hwang casts a white man named Marcus as an Asian in the play Face Values. This play itself was inspired by the casting of Jonathan Pryce in an Asian role for Miss Saigon.
